a_faq_runtime_api_key_distinction:
Q: What is the difference between 'Translation Service Keys' and 'Runtime API Key'?
A: Translation Service Keys (OpenAI, DeepL) are used in the Unity Editor to generate translations. They are stored in your computer's registry (EditorPrefs) and are NOT included in the build.
The Runtime API Key is used by the Game Build to fetch Live Updates. It IS included in the build (encrypted).

Mass Actions: Execute operations on thousands of cells at once. Right-click your selection to:
  • Auto-Translate: Fill missing translations using the active AI Profile.
  • Fill from Source: Quickly reset translations.
  • Toggle Lock: Protect 'perfect' translations from accidental overwrites.
  • Generate Audio: Batch process TTS for selected phrases.
li_editor_5: High-Performance Navigation: The editor uses a virtualized 'MultiColumnListView' for smooth scrolling with 10k+ keys. Supports keyboard navigation (Arrows/Tab) and industrial-strength shortcuts: Ctrl+S (Save), Ctrl+Z/Y (Undo/Redo), Ctrl+F (Search focus).
li_editor_6:
Advanced Search Presets: Audit your project using specialized filters:
  • Status: Untranslated (Current/Any Lang), Identical to Source, Locked.
  • Content: Has Comments, Has/Missing Placeholders, Has Length Issues (Auto-detected).
  • Structure: Pluralized, Gendered, or Both.
  • Audio: Missing Audio, Outdated (Hash Mismatch).
li_editor_7: Smart Audio Management: Tracks the 'freshness' of your TTS files. If you edit the translation text, a Yellow Indicator (Outdated) appears, indicating that the audio file hash no longer matches the text. One click regenerates only the stale files.
li_editor_8:
Locking Mechanism: Explanation:
  • Locked Cells/Rows: Prevents any modification by Auto-Translate, CSV/Google Import, or Fill from Source.
  • Use Case: Lock 'Golden' translations that have been manually verified by native speakers.
  • Bulk Control: Lock entire languages or specific features (like character names) project-wide.
li_editor_layout: Dynamic Multi-Pane Layout: Use the 3-pane system to pin 'fixed' columns (like Keys) to the left side while scrolling through 20+ languages in the middle. Toggle column visibility via the header context menu.
li_editor_regex: Regex Search: Both the main window and the table editor support Regular Expressions. If your query contains symbols like * + ? ^ $ [ ] ( ) { } | ., it is automatically treated as a Regex (e.g., ^item_.* to find all keys starting with 'item_').
li_editor_structure: Tables & Groups: Data is organized in Tables (Files), displayed as Groups (Folders) in the editor for better navigation.
li_editor_ui_test:
Built-in UI Testing:
  • Length Expansion Slider: Simulate text expansion (0% - 100%) to see how your UI handles longer languages like German or Russian without leaving the editor.
  • Rich Text Renderer: Toggle rendering of tags (<b>, <color>) to verify styling without running the game.

How to use: Simply add the LanguageSelector component to your scene (e.g., on an empty GameObject) and specify your TMP_Dropdown in the inspector.
li_example_components_2: Code Examples: To learn advanced techniques such as working with [LocalizableField], the _() function, plurals, and gender, study the StatPurchaseTest.cs and TestLocalization.cs files. They clearly demonstrate the implementation of all the main features of the tool in code.

li_migration_csv_details_1: Smart Filtering: The importer automatically skips rows that look like asset paths (e.g. .png, .mp3, Assets/...) to keep your text database clean.
li_migration_csv_details_2: 'Type' Column: If a 'Type' column exists (I2 format), only rows marked as 'Text' or with empty type are imported. To import assets, use the Migration Profiles to map them to LocalizedAsset.
li_migration_csv_req_1: Key Column: Must be named Key (case-insensitive) or defined in your Migration Profile.
li_migration_csv_req_2: Language Columns: Any column not marked as ignored is treated as a language code (e.g., 'en', 'ja', 'English'). The tool attempts to fuzzy-match these to your project's languages.
li_migration_csv_req_3: Comments: Columns named Desc, Description, or Comment are imported as developer notes. This list is configurable in the Migration Profile.
li_migration_custom_1: Right-click in Project View -> Create -> Anko Localization -> Migration Profile.
li_migration_custom_2: Rules: Define conversion rules (if [Source Component] with [Context Filter], then convert to [Target Component]). Rules support Priority (higher numbers processed first), Harvest Assets (automatically extract and register referenced assets like Sprites or Audio), and Context Filtering to distinguish between multiple components on the same object.
li_migration_fallback_keys: Fallback Key Fields: Specify additional field names to check when extracting keys from legacy components. Useful if your old system uses non-standard property names for keys.
li_migration_gs_1: Access: The sheet must be shared ('Anyone with the link can view') or Published to the Web.
li_migration_gs_2: Sheet Tabs (GID): The URL must include the gid=... parameter. This tells the tool exactly which tab to read (e.g. gid=0 is usually the first tab/sheet).
li_migration_ignored_headers: Ignored CSV Headers: Define columns that should be skipped during import (e.g., 'Type', 'Description'). This prevents the tool from treating metadata columns as language data.
li_migration_legacy_components: Additional Legacy Components: Manually list component names that the tool should detect as 'legacy' during the migration scan, even if no direct conversion rule is defined.
li_migration_profile_details:
Advanced Profile Settings:
  • CsvKeyHeader: The header name for the Key column.
  • CsvCommentHeaders: List of headers to treat as developer notes/comments.
  • IgnoredCsvHeaders: Columns to skip (metadata like 'Type' or 'Status') to avoid them being treated as languages.
  • AssetExtensions: File types recognized as assets during scanning.
  • FallbackKeyFields: Additional field names to check if the primary key field is empty.
li_migration_rule_fields:
Rule Configuration:
  • Priority: Higher values are processed first. Use this to handle specific cases before generic ones.
  • Context Filter: Only apply rule if a specific component (e.g., Text) is present on the same object.
  • Harvest Assets: If enabled, extracts the current asset (e.g., Sprite) from the legacy component and registers it in the asset table.
  • Asset Field Path: Path to the field containing the asset reference for harvesting.
  • Additional Data Path: Used for complex components like Dropdowns to harvest multiple values/options.
li_migration_stubs_1: Problem: You delete the old plugin assets. Unity detects missing scripts (e.g. Localize component missing). The editor enters compilation error mode.
li_migration_stubs_2: Solution: The 'Emergency Stubs' feature generates lightweight, empty classes with the exact same names and namespaces as the old plugin. This satisfies the compiler.
li_migration_stubs_3: Workflow: 1. Click Enable Emergency Stubs (this adds ANKO_ENABLE_MIGRATION_STUBS to your Project Settings). 2. Delete the old plugin folder. 3. Unity recompiles successfully using fake classes. 4. Run the Component Converter to replace stubs with official components. 5. Click Disable Stubs once refactoring is complete.
li_migration_tool_converter: Step 2: Component Converter: Scan scenes and prefabs. Automatically replaces old components (e.g., Localize) with LocalizedText / LocalizedAsset, transferring keys.
li_migration_tool_fields: Profile Settings: Configurable 'Source Plugin' type and 'Asset Mapping' rules ensure correct transfer of textures and audio.
li_migration_tool_import: Step 1: Data Import: Import CSV (I2) or XLIFF (Unity Loc) files to create a key database.
li_migration_tool_profiles: Migration Profiles: Create custom profiles to map assets and settings from 3rd party plugins (I2, Unity Loc).
li_migration_tool_safemode: Safe Mode & Emergency Stubs: Components are disabled rather than deleted. Includes the critical Emergency Stubs feature (activated via the ANKO_ENABLE_MIGRATION_STUBS define symbol): generates fake placeholder classes for I2 Localization or Unity Localization so your project can compile immediately after removing those plugins. This prevents "The type name 'Localize' could not be found" errors and gives you time to properly refactor your code to use the new system. Enable Stubs allows you to fix compilation errors after deleting the old localization plugin.
li_migration_tool_setup: Step 0: Setup: Configure component names (e.g., Localize for I2) and fields where the key is stored. Presets are available.
li_migration_workflow_1: 1. Backup: Commit your project into source control (Git) or make a file backup before starting.
li_migration_workflow_2: 2. Enable Stubs: Open Migration Tool -> 'Safe Mode' tab. Click Enable Emergency Stubs for your target system (I2/UnityLoc). This creates lightweight fake classes in your project.
li_migration_workflow_3: 3. Remove Old Plugin: Delete the old plugin folder (e.g., 'Assets/Plugins/I2'). Unity will recompile. Thanks to Stubs, you will NOT get 'Type not found' errors, preserving all your component references on prefabs.
li_migration_workflow_4: 4. Import Data: In 'Import Data' tab, load your Source CSV/XLIFF. Verify the preview and click Import. This populates the AnKo translation tables.
li_migration_workflow_5: 5. Convert Components: In 'Component Converter' tab, select 'Entire Project' and click Scan & Convert. The tool replaces old stubs with 'LocalizedText'/'LocalizedAsset' components, transferring the keys.
li_migration_workflow_6: 6. Cleanup: Once everything is working, click Disable Stubs and let Unity recompile again.
li_notes_1: Backups: Always create a backup via Translation Table Editor -> Manage Backups before major changes. Backups are stored in the LocalizationBackups folder at the project root (outside the Assets folder) to keep your Unity project clean and reduce import times.
li_notes_2: API Key Security: The key for working in the editor is stored locally on your machine (in EditorPrefs) and does not get into the repository. For keys needed in the game build, use the Runtime API Key section.
li_notes_3: StreamingAssets Folder: Translation files must be in a subfolder of Assets/StreamingAssets/ to be included in the game build.
li_notes_4: "Fool-proofing": The tool automatically protects you from accidentally saving temporary data from preview mode into a scene or prefab.
li_notes_5: Performance: The _() call is fast, but in loops that run every frame (e.g., in Update), try to cache the result in a variable.
li_notes_6: Excluding LanguageSelector from parsing: The object with the LanguageSelector component and its TMP_Dropdown must be added to the Ignore Specific Objects list in the Content tab. This is necessary to prevent the parser from creating extra keys for the dropdown options, as the LanguageSelector script populates them dynamically at runtime. Ignoring prevents conflicts and keeps the translation files clean.
li_notes_7: Fonts for LanguageSelector: For the selected language in the TMP_Dropdown to correctly update its font, manually add an empty LocalizedText component to the child Label object of the Dropdown and check the isStyleOnly box.
li_notes_addressables_code: Code & Addressables: If you switch to Addressables (Async) mode, you MUST use GetLocalizedAssetAsync() in your scripts. Calling the synchronous GetLocalizedAsset() will return null and log a warning to prevent main thread freezes.
li_notes_addressables_sync_warning: Sync vs Async: If you switch to Addressables (Async) mode, you MUST update your code to use GetLocalizedAssetAsync(). Calling the synchronous method will return null and log a warning to avoid freezing the main thread.
li_preview_1: How it works: Select a language from the list, and the tool will instantly apply the corresponding translations, fonts, RTL settings, and assets to all localizable objects in the active scene or opened prefab.

li_settings_1:
Key Generation Mode: Defines the strategy for creating unique identifiers for your text:
  • AutoGenerateKeysOnly (Default - Recommended): Generates keys based on scene/prefab name and object hierarchy (e.g., scene_Menu_BtnPlay_682412). Best for large projects as it guarantees uniqueness and is immune to text changes.
  • UseTextAsKey: Uses the source text itself as the key (e.g., "Start Game" → Start Game). Ideal for rapid prototyping where keys should be human-readable.
  • AutoGenerateWithCustomKeys (Hybrid): The most flexible mode. It first checks if a component already has a manually assigned key or a [LocalizableField(key="...")]. If no key exists, it generates a hierarchical one. Use this to preserve existing work while automating new content.
  • UseTextAsKeyWithCustomPriority (Hybrid): Like the above, but falls back to the text itself if no manual key is found. Respects existing components and data.
  • Manual: The scanner never creates new keys. It only updates objects that already have a localization component with a key. Perfect for strict manual control.
li_settings_10: Dev Tools: At the bottom of the Settings tab, you can find utility buttons like Clear Saved Language Pref (resets the saved language in PlayerPrefs so the game starts with the Default language again).
li_settings_11: Technical Dropdown Options: A list of string values (defaults: 'Option A', 'Option B', 'Option C') that the parser will ignore when scanning Dropdowns. This keeps your translation table clean from Unity's default UI placeholder text.
li_settings_2:
Language Management:
  • Source Language: The language used in your Unity scenes/prefabs (development language).
  • Default Language: The language selected on the first game launch if the user's system language is not supported.
  • List: Manage supported languages, assign specific Font Assets, and enable RTL support.
li_settings_3:
General Settings: Configuration for project-wide behavior:
  • Translations Save Path: The root directory for storing .json translation files. For in-game access, this must be inside Assets/Resources or Assets/StreamingAssets.
  • Safe Mode: A protection layer that blocks operations (like Auto-Translate) if project inconsistencies or missing dependencies are detected.
  • Remove Missing Keys: If enabled, the scanner will automatically delete entries from the database that are no longer present in any scene or prefab during project update.
  • Parse Inactive Objects: Determines whether the tool should scan and localize disabled or hidden GameObjects.
  • Parse All Prefabs: Scans every prefab in the project. If disabled, only prefabs in folders specified in the Content tab are processed.
  • Fill Comments By Paths: Automatically populates the 'Comment' field in the translation table with the object's scene/prefab hierarchy path.
  • Split Files by Language: Divides the translation database into multiple files (e.g., en.json, ja.json). Highly recommended for large projects to reduce runtime memory overhead.
  • Allow Empty Source/Keys: Allows the tool to register and track objects even if their source text is empty. Useful for dynamic text that is set exclusively via code.
  • Attach to Regex-Ignored Text: Compels the tool to add localization components to objects whose text matches an exclusion regex (like numbers), allowing for manual override.
  • Find Settings Asset: A utility button that instantly pings and selects the LocalizationSettings.asset file in your Project window.
li_settings_4:
Debugging & Testing:
  • Placeholder Style: Choose the style for displaying placeholders in preview mode.
  • Pseudo-Localization: Select 'Custom Pseudo' to reveal advanced layout testing settings (Expansion Factor, Accents, and Delimiters).
li_settings_5: Live Updates: Settings for loading translations from a remote server.
li_settings_6: Runtime API Key: Securely stores your API key for Live Updates (fetching new translations in-game). This is different from the Translation Service keys used in the Editor. The key is obfuscated (encrypted) in the build to prevent easy extraction via string search, but remember: no client-side secret is 100% secure.
li_settings_7: Asset Loading Strategy: Choice between Resources (Legacy), Addressables (Async), and Custom. Warning: Changing this mode requires a project re-scan. Addressables mode is highly recommended for mobile and WebGL to reduce memory usage.
li_settings_8:
Auto-Translation: Uses the Translation Profiles system for AI-driven localization. Configuration includes:
  • Text & Audio Profiles: Select or create ScriptableObject profiles to configure different services (e.g., OpenAI, DeepL, Google).
  • Presets Folder: The directory where your translation presets and profiles are stored.
  • Target Languages: A list of all project languages with real-time status, progress bars, and character counts for the selected profile.
  • Start Auto Translation: Begins the process for all selected languages using the specified profiles.
li_settings_9:
Debugging Enhancements:
  • Show Hierarchy Icons: Displays status icons (Green Tick / Yellow Warning) in the hierarchy. Performance Optimized: Uses caching to ensure zero lag even in large scenes.
  • Show Scene View Labels: Visual debugging directly in the Scene View. Labels are interactive: Right-click on any scene label to instantly copy the localization key to the clipboard.
li_settings_asset_folder_rule: Folder Structure Rule: Defines how subfolders are structured when generating localized assets (e.g., {lang}/{category}).
li_settings_bridge_name: Bridge Class Name: Allows you to customize the name of the generated static class (default is AnkoLoc).
li_settings_general_safe_mode: Safe Mode: Ensures that critical operations won't proceed if they might cause inconsistent project states.
li_settings_icons_legend:
Hierarchy Icons Legend:
🟢 (Green Tick): Localized & Key set.
🔴 (Red Error): Localized component present, but Key is missing.
🟡 (Yellow Warn): Text/Image component found, but no Localization component attached.
🐛 (Bug): Object is Ignored by settings.
li_settings_lang_culture_fallback: Use Culture Fallback: If a specific regional dialect (e.g., en-AU) is missing, the tool will attempt to use the base language (en) before falling back to the Default Language.
li_settings_lang_follow_system: Follow System Language: Automatically switches the game language to match the player's OS language on the first launch.
li_settings_live_updates_security: Security: runtime API keys are encrypted (AES) in the build to prevent casual extraction. Always use HTTPS.
li_settings_pseudo_accents: Use Accents: Replaces standard characters with accented versions (e.g., å, é). Use this to ensure your fonts support all required glyphs.
li_settings_pseudo_brackets: Add Brackets: Wraps text in [ ] to verify the start and end of localized strings, helping identify text truncation or concatenation issues.
li_settings_pseudo_expand_length: Expand Length: Simulates text expansion common in languages like German or Russian by appending trailing characters.
li_settings_pseudo_expansion_factor: Expansion Factor: Multiplier for text length simulation (e.g., 2.0 will make the text twice as long).
li_settings_pseudo_prefix: Custom Prefix: Add a specific string (like PSEUDO-) to the beginning of every localized text.
li_settings_pseudo_suffix: Custom Suffix: Add a specific string to the end of every localized text.
li_settings_return_source: Return Source if Missing: If enabled, the system will return the text in the source language (or the key itself) if no translation is found for the current language.
li_settings_tms_timeout: TMS Timeout: Specifies the maximum wait time (in seconds) for network requests to external TMS services.
li_settings_tool_check_deps: Check Dependencies: Re-scans the project for required packages (like Newtonsoft) and optional integrations.
li_settings_tool_cleanup: Full Project Cleanup: A destructive tool that removes all Anko Localization components and data from the project (use with caution!).
li_settings_tool_clear_prefs: Clear Language Prefs: Resets the saved language in PlayerPrefs, forcing the game to use the default or system language on next launch.
li_settings_tool_font_manager: Font Manager: Opens the Font & Glyph Manager to analyze missing characters and generate optimized font assets.
li_settings_tool_migration: Migration Tool: Facilitates moving data and components from I2 Localization or Unity Localization.
li_settings_tool_test_center: Localization Test Center: A diagnostic tool for verifying project health, checking for broken references, and ensuring localization integrity.

p_ai_intro: The tool uses a Translation Profile system (ScriptableObject). This keeps translation service settings in individual profile assets, allowing you to switch configurations easily.
p_api_snippets_intro: The LocalizationManager.cs provides a robust API for runtime localization management. Below are the key methods you'll use in your scripts.
p_assets_1: This tab is entirely dedicated to localizing non-text resources.
p_async_api: When using Addressables, assets are not loaded instantly. You must use the asynchronous API to prevent frame drops.
p_bridge_description: The tool includes a static class generator for key access, allowing you to use strongly typed references instead of magic strings. This helps prevent typos and enables IDE autocompletion.
p_components_intro: These components are the "bridge" between your objects in the scene and the translation database. They "listen" for language changes and automatically substitute the correct text or asset.
p_content_1: Here you tell the tool where exactly to look for text. The interface has been completely redesigned for better usability.
p_custom_ai: The Custom AI service type allows you to connect any LLM via REST API.
p_custom_asset_provider_1: Developing a custom provider allows you to integrate your own asset management system (e.g., a custom cloud loader, a specific internal bundling system, or a database-driven asset repository) directly into the localization workflow.
p_custom_asset_provider_intro: The Asset Provider system abstracts how assets (Sprites, Audio, Prefabs, etc.) are loaded at runtime. It uses a Plugin Registry that automatically discovers any class implementation of IAssetProvider marked with the [AssetProviderPlugin] attribute. This allows for seamless integration of custom loading systems (like cloud loaders or internal bundling) without modifying the core toolkit.
p_custom_attributes_description: In addition to function calls, you can mark any string field in your scripts as localizable using custom attributes. By default, the tool recognizes [LocalizableField], but you can add any attribute name (like [Header] or [Tooltip]) to the Attributes to Scan list.
p_custom_parser_1: You can easily extend the system to support custom components by creating your own parser class.
p_editor_1: Opens via Tools -> Localization -> Translation Table Editor. This is the main tool for manually editing translations.
p_example_attribute_1: The most powerful way to localize script variables. It works with private, protected, and public fields. The parser recursively handles Arrays, Lists, and Nested Serializable Classes. It can even generate keys for other attributes (like [Header] or [Tooltip]) if configured in Settings.
p_example_components_1: The project includes ready-to-use scripts that serve as excellent examples.
p_example_components_updated: The code has changed. The language loading (especially when using Addressables) is now asynchronous.
p_example_function_1: Use the _() function for dynamic text that changes during gameplay. The method that updates the UI should be marked with the [OnLanguageChange] attribute so that it is called automatically when the language is changed. A LocalizedBehaviour component will be automatically added to the object for this purpose.
p_example_plurals_1: The tool now uses more accurate rules for different language groups.
p_font_glyph_manager_access: Access via Tools -> Anko Localization Tool -> Font & Glyph Manager.
p_intro_1: This tool is a comprehensive solution for localizing games and applications in Unity. It automates the process of collecting text and assets, managing translations through a powerful interface, integrating with machine translation services (including Custom AI), and dynamically updating localized content in the game.
p_live_updates_guide: The Live Updates system allows your game to fetch new translations from a remote server or Google Sheet at runtime, without requiring a new build.
p_localizedasset_1:
Used to swap assets based on language. Automatically detects the component type. Supports:
  • 2D: Sprites (Image, SpriteRenderer), Textures (RawImage).
  • Audio/Video: AudioSource, VideoPlayer.
  • 3D/Animation: MeshFilter (Meshes), Renderer (Materials), Animator (Controller), PlayableDirector (Timeline).
p_localizedasset_2: For components with the Play on Awake option (like AudioSource, VideoPlayer), LocalizedAsset correctly intercepts the auto-play, swaps the asset, and then starts playback to avoid playing unlocalized content.
p_localizedasset_updated: The component now supports asynchronous loading. Note that there may be a slight delay when changing languages if assets are loaded from cloud/disk (Addressables).
p_localizedbehaviour_1: A utility component that allows your scripts to react to language changes. It automatically finds and calls methods marked with the [OnLanguageChange] attribute.
p_localizeddropdown_1: Added to Dropdown and TMP_Dropdown to translate their options.
p_localizedprefab_1: A component for localizing entire prefabs. It works non-destructively: it does not modify the original prefab but creates an instance of the localized version as a child object, disabling all scripts (MonoBehaviour), renderers (Renderer), and colliders (Collider) on the original object. This prevents dual logic execution and visual artifacts. For correct runtime operation, its execution order is set to -100 ([DefaultExecutionOrder(-100)]) to ensure it runs before other scripts.
p_localizedtext_1: The main component for displaying translated text. It is placed on objects with Text, TMP_Text, and TextMesh.
p_migration_custom: You can create your own migration profiles to support custom systems or specific project setups. Each profile contains a list of Rules that define how components and their fields should be converted. Rules are checked in order of their Priority.
p_migration_custom_advanced: Migration Profiles offer advanced settings for fine-tuning the import and detection process:
p_migration_google_sheet: You can import directly from a Google Sheet URL without downloading files.
p_migration_import_csv: The tool supports standard CSV files (comma-separated). The first row must be the header.
p_migration_stubs: A common issue when migrating is that deleting the old plugin (e.g. I2) breaks the build, preventing Unity from compiling the Migration Tool itself.
p_migration_tool_access: Access via Tools -> Anko Localization Tool -> Migration Tool.
p_migration_tool_desc: Tool for transitioning from other localization systems (I2 Localization, Unity Localization).
p_preview_1: Directly below the header is the Preview Language dropdown list. This powerful feature allows you to see how the localization will look in any language directly in the Scene window or Prefab Mode, without running the game.
p_preview_overlay: For even faster iteration, you can switch languages directly from the Scene View using the dedicated Localization Preview Overlay.
p_report_1: After each parsing, this report shows the full picture of your localization status.
p_safety_caps: To prevent accidental high costs or large traffic checks:
p_script_parsing_rules_description: The tool can be configured to recognize localization keys used in custom functions or even competitor systems (like I2 Localization) without modifying your existing code. This is achieved by defining regex patterns that the scanner uses to extract keys from your scripts.
p_script_parsing_rules_usage: In the Content tab, under Script Parsing Rules, you can add rules that match your specific function calls. For example, to support I2.Loc.Get("key"), you can add a rule with a pattern that captures the string inside the parentheses.
p_settings_1: Your control center. Here you define global rules for the entire localization process.
p_tms_intro: The tool now supports synchronization with popular Translation Management Systems. You can push source keys and pull translations directly within Unity.
p_tms_setup:
1. Go to Settings -> TMS Integration.
2. Select your service provider.
3. Enter the API Keys and Project IDs.
4. Use the Push (Upload Keys) and Pull (Download Translations) buttons in the Settings window.
p_tutorials_1: The Tutorials tab provides interactive step-by-step guides to help you master the tool's features directly within the Unity Editor.
p_uitklocalization_1: Added to objects with a UIDocument. Supports localization of Labels, Buttons, HelpBox, Foldout, ProgressBar (title), TextField (label & placeholder), DropdownField (label & choices), RadioButton, RadioButtonGroup, ToggleButtonGroup (Unity 2023+), and Tooltips on any element. Identifiers are stable across renames if IDs are set in UI Builder.
p_window_footer: Displays the current status, progress of background operations, and the tool version.
p_window_header: The top bar provides global access to preview controls and utility tools that persist regardless of the selected tab.
p_window_sidebar: The sidebar handles navigation between different functional tabs and global search tools.
